results.abstract: Rep Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona plans to travel to Florida to watch final launch of space shuttle Endeavor, to be led by her astronaut husband Capt Mark E Kelly (S)

headline.main: Arizona: Rep. Giffords Will Return for Launching

results.snippet: A spokesman for Representative Gabrielle Giffords said she planned to return to Florida to watch her astronaut husband lead the final launching of the space shuttle Endeavour when the flight is rescheduled.
results.lead_paragraph: A spokesman for Representative Gabrielle Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, said she planned to return to Florida to watch her astronaut husband lead the final launching of the space shuttleEndeavour when the flight is rescheduled. Ms. Giffords had traveled from Houston to Cape Canaveral to watch the launching scheduled for last Friday, which was delayed because of a technical problem. She has returned to the Houston rehabilitation hospital where she is being treated after being shot in the head in January while meeting with constituents. The launching is off until at least May 10.

results.abstract: As a counterpoint to my weekly carping, here's my latest small sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions. (Feel free to use the comments section to point out your own recent favorites.)

results.lead_paragraph: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

results.abstract: How can I leave the city I love?
results.snippet: How can I leave the city I love?
results.lead_paragraph: My first New York apartment was a 9-by-5-foot room on 20th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It was an all-female boarding house, or S.R.O. (single room occupancy) as they were called before my time. The eight women on my floor all lived in cell-like rooms, and shared the two tiny bathrooms in the hallway, one with nothing but a toilet, the other with a moldy shower.

results.abstract: Chevrolet Corvettes chauffeured American astronauts through Cocoa Beach, Fla., on Saturday in a commemorative parade.

headline.main: A Parade of Astronauts and Corvettes

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

results.snippet: Chevrolet Corvettes chauffeured American astronauts through Cocoa Beach, Fla., on Saturday in a commemorative parade.
results.lead_paragraph: A group of current and former NASA astronauts gathered in Cocoa Beach, Fla., on Saturday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Alan Shepard's suborbital flight. The event was marked by a parade, with the astronauts riding in a fleet of Chevrolet Corvettes that included examples of the sports car's six design iterations.

results.snippet: The transcript of President Obama’s remarks on Wednesday in El Paso, as released by the White House.
results.lead_paragraph: Following is a text of President Obama's remarks on immigration, delivered Tuesday in El Paso, as released by the White House: THE PRESIDENT: Hello, El Paso! (Applause.) Well, it is wonderful -- wonderful to be back with all of you in the Lone Star State. (Applause.) Everything is bigger in Texas. (Applause.)

results.abstract: NASA makes final preparations for the launching of the shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station, the next to last in the 30-year shuttle program; Endeavour's six-man crew will be led by Capt Mark E Kelly; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Endeavour Is Readied, Once Again, for Its Final Launching

results.snippet: NASA made final preparations for sending the shuttle Endeavour to the International Space Station, confident it had resolved an electrical problem that grounded it two weeks ago.
results.lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- NASA made final preparations on Sunday for the launching of the shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station, confident that it had fixed an electrical problem that grounded the spacecraft two weeks earlier. Officials reported no new major technical glitches but were keeping an eye on the weather, saying there was a chance that low clouds or high winds could postpone the launching -- scheduled for 8:56 a.m. Monday -- for a day or more. The mission, which is expected to last 16 days, will be the 134th and next to last in the 30-year shuttle program, with only a flight by the Atlantis, scheduled for this summer, remaining.

headline.seo: Endeavour Lifts Off on Its Final Flight
headline.print_headline: Closely Watched Space Shuttle Has Its Last Liftoff
headline.main: Endeavour Lifts Off on Its Final Flight

results.snippet: Led by Capt. Mark E. Kelly, Gabrielle Giffords’s husband, the mission is headed to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: Led by Capt. Mark E. Kelly, Gabrielle Giffords’s husband, the mission is headed to the International Space Station.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour lifts off for final time from Kennedy Space Station in Florida to meet up with International Space Station; shuttle is commanded by Capt Mark E Kelly, husband of Arizona congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords; photos (M)

headline.main: Closely Watched Space Shuttle Has Its Last Liftoff

results.snippet: Led by Capt. Mark E. Kelly, Gabrielle Giffords’s husband, the mission is headed to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- With Gabrielle Giffords, the wounded Arizona congresswoman, watching from a wheelchair, the shuttle Endeavour lifted off Monday morning on a mission to pry secrets from the universe. At 8:56 a.m. Eastern time, the spacecraft rose slowly on a pillar of fire, picking up speed and eventually disappearing from view as it stabbed through a layer of clouds on its way to orbit. Commanding the six-man crew was Capt. Mark E. Kelly, Ms. Giffords's husband.

results.abstract: Guy Laliberté, stilt walker, fire eater and now astrotourist, talks about his space scrapbook, "Gaia," published by Assouline, in an exclusive interview.
results.snippet: Guy Laliberté, stilt walker, fire eater and now astrotourist, talks about his space scrapbook, "Gaia," published by Assouline, in an exclusive interview.
results.lead_paragraph: What might Guy Laliberté do next? He was a stilt walker and fire eater in Montreal before founding Cirque du Soleil in 1984. He later became a world-class competitive poker player, and in 2009 he rocketed into space as one of the first astrotourists. A study in teleology as much as topography, ''Gaia'' (Assouline, $65) is his space scrapbook, filled with digital photos that zoom in on dramatically abstract 300-square-mile swaths of Earth. ''Day after day, I was amazed by the beauty of this planet,'' he said. ''It is an infinite living art in motion.'' The full text of T's exclusive interview with Laliberté is after the jump.

headline.main: APNewsBreak: Giffords Set to Undergo Skull Surgery

results.snippet: Doctors will replace a piece of Gabrielle Giffords' skull with a plastic implant on Wednesday, another encouraging step in the Arizona congresswoman's recovery from a gunshot to the head more than four months ago.
results.lead_paragraph: Doctors will replace a piece of Gabrielle Giffords' skull with a plastic implant on Wednesday, another encouraging step in the Arizona congresswoman's recovery from a gunshot to the head more than four months ago.

results.abstract: Doctors for Rep Gabrielle Giffords say surgery to restore large piece of her cranium with ceramic prosthesis was success and that her progress is 'almost miraculous'; photo (M)

headline.main: Giffords's Doctors Remain Upbeat After Operation

results.snippet: Surgeons used a ceramic prosthesis to replace a piece of Representative Gabrielle Giffords’s skull that was removed to relieve swelling after she was shot.
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON -- Representative Gabrielle Giffords was resting in an intensive care unit on Thursday after undergoing surgery to restore a large piece of her cranium with a ceramic prosthesis and install a permanent tube to drain fluid from her skull. The surgery marked an important milestone in Ms. Giffords's recovery from an assassination attempt in a Tucson supermarket parking lot on Jan. 8. A gunman shot her in the forehead as she met with constituents, in a rampage that left six dead, among them a federal judge and a 9-year-old girl.

results.snippet: What might Guy Laliberte do next? He was a stilt walker and fire eater in Montreal before founding Cirque du Soleil in 1984. He later became a world-class competitive poker player, and in 2009 he rocketed into space as one of the first astrotourists....
results.lead_paragraph: What might Guy Laliberte do next? He was a stilt walker and fire eater in Montreal before founding Cirque du Soleil in 1984. He later became a world-class competitive poker player, and in 2009 he rocketed into space as one of the first astrotourists. A study in teleology as much as topography, ''Gaia'' (Assouline, $65) is his space scrapbook, filled with digital photos that zoom in on dramatically abstract 300-square-mile swaths of Earth. ''Day after day, I was amazed by the beauty of this planet,'' he said. ''It is an infinite living art in motion.'' The full text of T's exclusive interview with Laliberte is after the jump. Q.I wanted to start by asking you about the title page. You say the book is ''curated'' by you? Why did you choose that phrasing when you actually went into space and took these photographs yourself?

results.abstract: John M Logsdon book John F Kennedy and the Race to the Moon draws on research in recently-available archives, oral histories and memoirs to shed new light on NASA's first Apollo Mission; photo (M)

headline.main: Race to Space, Through the Lens of Time

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: JOHN F KENNEDY AND THE RACE TO THE MOON (BOOK)

results.snippet: It was the spring of 1961. President John F. Kennedy, speaking of new frontiers and projecting the vigor of youth, had been in office barely four months, and April had been the cruelest.     On the 12th, Yuri Gagarin became the first human to orbit...
results.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 1961. President John F. Kennedy, speaking of new frontiers and projecting the vigor of youth, had been in office barely four months, and April had been the cruelest. On the 12th, Yuri Gagarin became the first human to orbit Earth -- one more space triumph for the Soviet Union. Though the flight was not unexpected, it was nonetheless deflating; it would be more than a month before Alan Shepard became the first American in space, and that was on a 15-minute suborbital flight. On the 17th, a force of anti-Castro exiles, trained by the C.I.A., invaded communist Cuba at the Bay of Pigs -- a fiasco within 36 hours. Mr. Kennedy's close aide Theodore Sorensen described him on the 19th as ''anguished and fatigued'' and ''in the most emotional, self-critical state I had ever seen him.''

results.abstract: Joe Sharkey On The Road column on company Row 44, which uses amphibious plane as laboratory to create better technologies for air travel; notes that Row 44 is best known for its introduction of broadband Wi-Fi connectivity; drawing (M)

headline.main: Innovation in the Air Can Begin on the Water

results.snippet: Row 44, a California company, uses an amphibious plane as a lab for better technologies that eventually make their way into jets.
results.lead_paragraph: MOST aeronautical and technological innovations in airplanes initially involve a guy like Dave Cummings in the cockpit, testing out new equipment under various conditions. Well, maybe not exactly like Mr. Cummings, a former bush pilot in Alaska who told me he had been through a couple of dozen cockpit fires and other adventures in severe conditions.

headline.main: Race to Space, Through the Lens of Time

results.snippet: A space policy specialist has drawn on new research in archives, oral histories and memoirs to reassess the meaning of Project Apollo 50 years after its start.
results.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 1961. President John F. Kennedy, speaking of new frontiers and projecting the vigor of youth, had been in office barely four months, and April had been the cruelest. On the 12th, Yuri Gagarin became the first human to orbit Earth -- one more space triumph for the Soviet Union. Though the flight was not unexpected, it was nonetheless deflating; it would be more than a month before Alan Shepard became the first American in space, and that was on a 15-minute suborbital flight. On the 17th, a force of anti-Castro exiles, trained by the C.I.A., invaded communist Cuba at the Bay of Pigs -- a fiasco within 36 hours. Mr. Kennedy's close aide Theodore Sorensen described him on the 19th as ''anguished and fatigued'' and ''in the most emotional, self-critical state I had ever seen him.''
